Award.AwardTitle: US-Denmark-Czech Republic-China planning visit to develop an integrative approach to understanding range expansions and biological invasions under global change regimes
Award.AbstractNarration:
US-China planning visit to develop an integrative approach to understanding range expansion and invasiveness of plants under global change regimes.

Global climate change is predicted to have profound effects on species range expansions within continents and species invasions across continents. At present, few studies have examined the effects of global environmental change (GEC) on the interactions between invasive plant species and the native plants, animals and other organisms in the invaded community. Moreover, no studies have attempted to integrate disparate scientific fields such as genetics, physiology, geography and ecology, to determine the mechanisms underlying the effects of GEC on native-invasive species interactions. Such an integrated approach can lead to a greater ability to predict novel plant-herbivore interactions (e.g., acquiring new herbivores during range expansion of a plant) which may be one of the more serious consequences of global climate change.

The proposed projects involves a partnership between Co-Investigators Cronin and Meyerson and Hans Brix (Aarhus University, Denmark), Petr Pysek (The Institute of Botany, Czech Republic), and Renqing Wang (Shandong University, China; SDU) to strengthen a network of global scientists working to predict and address the effects of GEC on plant genetics, physiology and interactions with native plants and herbivores. Collaborations already exist between US and European partners, but inclusion of Professor Wang into this collaboration is essential and would represent a new partnership. The project will focus on a global network of experimental gardens (one at each of the five partner institutions) containing specimens of the plant species Phragmites australis collected from all over the world. P. australis is a model study system because it has a global distribution, high genetic diversity, wide latitudinal range (+/-60o), ready availability of both modern and historical samples, and is invasive on some continents. The complementary resources and skills (botany, ecophysiology, statistical modeling, ecology and genetics) and international experience of the proposal partners and supporting organizations will allow researchers to investigate the spatial, temporal and genetic patterns in the distribution of P. australis resulting from past, present, and future GEC. Overall, the collaboration will increase the scale, scope, and capacity of research of all partners and offer opportunities for interdisciplinary research efforts with fields such as economics, policy, and sociology.

To establish a new partnership with Professor Wang and SDU, Cronin and Meyerson, along with one student from each lab, will travel to SDU to meet Prof. Wang and his research group. The objectives and associated activities from this visit are four fold. (1) Initiate the establishment of a complementary common garden at SDU. (2) With the assistance of Prof. Wang, collect proof-of-concept data on P. australis physiology, genetics, herbivory, defenses against herbivores, and plant growth. (3) Train and transfer knowledge amongst partners and their students through field demonstrations and web-based seminars. And (4) Foster long-term sustainable collaborative research amongst partner institutions. This project will provide international travel, mentorship and training for two graduate students. Students will have access not only to world renowned scientists in their field, but also to five common gardens and associated laboratory facilities to enable them to conduct cutting-edge international research on important societal and ecological problems. Outreach will include a general-public webinar series on invasion biology and global change ecology.

Global environmental change (GEC) is predicted to have profound effects on species range expansions and species invasions. A partnership was proposed between Co-Is Cronin (Louisiana State University; LSU) and Meyerson (University of Rhode Island; URI) and Hans Brix (Aarhus University, Denmark), Petr Pyšek (The Institute of Botany, Czech Republic), and Renqing Wang (Shandong University, China; SDU). The goal of this network of global scientists is to understand the effects of GEC on native-invasive species interactions. Such an integrated approach can lead to a greater ability to predict novel plant-herbivore interactions (e.g., acquiring new herbivores during range expansion of a plant) which may be one of the more serious consequences of global climate change. Collaborations already existed between US and European partners, but inclusion of Professor Wang at SDU
into this collaboration is essential and represented a new partnership.

A main objective of this collaboration is to establish a global network of experimental gardens containing specimens of the plant species Phragmites
australis collected from all over the world. P. australis is a model study system because it has a global distribution, high genetic diversity, wide latitudinal range, and is invasive on some continents.

PIs Cronin and Meyerson, along with senior undergraduate student Jordan Croy (LSU) and graduate student Sara Wigginton (URI) traveled to China in early July, 2015 to establish a new research partnership with Professor Wang. During this meeting, the following objectives were accomplished. (1) The PIs and students gave presentations on their research associated with invasive plant species as part of a workshop organized by Professor Wang. (2) Participants, along with Professor Wang and 12 members of his research group, visited the field station in Fanggon. A tour of the laboratories and visiting scientists housing was provided, and the care, maintenance and expansion of the common garden was discussed. (3) Professor Wang led a field trip to locate potential sources of P. australis and field sites for research. (4) Participants searched for and collected field data from P. australis patches along a longitudinal transect from Shandong Province to the Yunnan Province. (5) The PIs developed and provided Chinese partners with written protocols for the establishment and maintenance of common gardens. (6) Partners collected tissue samples for genetic and genomic analysis and data on herbivores and herbivory to provide proof-of-concept for our research objectives. (7) The PIs provided training and transfer of knowledge by giving presentations at the workshop hosted by Professor Wang, meeting with Chinese graduate students and local governmental dignitaries to discuss wetland restoration and the benefits of P. australis, and helping to organize a special symposium at the Society of Wetland Scientists annual meeting held in Providence, Rhode Island (May, 2015). (8) The PIs fostered long-term sustainable collaborative research amongst partner institutions by participating in a workshop in China, organizing an international symposium, and writing collaborative research proposals to fund the research objectives.

Training and professional development of the two students was enhanced through meetings and activities involving the two PIs, our European collaborators and Professor Wang and his research group. The Society of Wetland Scientists meeting in Rhode Island gave both students the unique opportunity to meet and interact with the world’s leading experts on invasion biology. Students also gained invaluable international experience and exposure to new cultures.
